head.title: Achieving Low VOC-deficit Characteristics in Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 Solar Cells through Improved Carrier Separation | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Achieving Low VOC-deficit Characteristics in Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 Solar Cells through Improved Carrier Separation

Kesterite-based thin-film solar cells (TFSCs) have recently gained significant attention in the photovoltaic (PV) sector for their elemental earth abundance and low toxicity. An inclusive study from the past reveals basic knowledge about the grain boundary (GB) and grain interior (GI) interface. However, the compositional dependency of the surface potential within GBs and GIs remains unclear. The present work provides insights into the surface potential of the bulk and GB interfaces. The tin (Sn) composition is sensitive to the absorber morphology, and therefore, it significantly impacts absorber and device properties. The absorber morphology improves with the formation of larger grains as the Sn content increases. Additionally, the presence of Sn(S,Se)2 and increased [ZnCu + VCu] A-type defect cluster density are observed, validated through Raman analysis. The secondary ion mass spectroscopy analysis reveals the altered distribution of sulfur (S) and sodium (Na) with higher near-surface accumulation. The synergistic outcome of the increased density of defects and the accumulation of S near the interface provides a larger GB and GI difference and expedites carrier separation improvement. Consequently, at an optimum compositional ratio of Cu/(Zn+Sn) = ∼0.6, the power conversion efficiency (PCE) is significantly improved from 6.42 to 11.04% with a record open-circuit voltage (VOC) deficit of 537 mV.

div.p:
Kesterite-based thin-film solar cells (TFSCs) have recently gained significant attention in the photovoltaic (PV) sector for their elemental earth abundance and low toxicity. An inclusive study from the past reveals basic knowledge about the grain boundary (GB) and grain interior (GI) interface. However, the compositional dependency of the surface potential within GBs and GIs remains unclear. The present work provides insights into the surface potential of the bulk and GB interfaces. The tin (Sn) composition is sensitive to the absorber morphology, and therefore, it significantly impacts absorber and device properties. The absorber morphology improves with the formation of larger grains as the Sn content increases. Additionally, the presence of Sn(S,Se)
2
and increased [Zn
Cu
+ V
Cu
] A-type defect cluster density are observed, validated through Raman analysis. The secondary ion mass spectroscopy analysis reveals the altered distribution of sulfur (S) and sodium (Na) with higher near-surface accumulation. The synergistic outcome of the increased density of defects and the accumulation of S near the interface provides a larger GB and GI difference and expedites carrier separation improvement. Consequently, at an optimum compositional ratio of Cu/(Zn+Sn) = ∼0.6, the power conversion efficiency (PCE) is significantly improved from 6.42 to 11.04% with a record open-circuit voltage (
V
OC
) deficit of 537 mV.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The kesterite family is a promising photoabsorber material for earth-abundant-element-based thin-film solar cells. Recently developed kesterite Cu
2
ZnSn(S,Se)
4
(CZTSSe) has the highest power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 12.62%, followed by 12.5 and 11% for Cu
2
ZnSnSe
4
(CZTSe) and Cu
2
ZnSnS
4
(CZTS), respectively.
(1−3)
Still, it is less than their preceding polycrystalline CuIn
(1–
x
)
Ga
(
x
)
Se
2
(CIGS), which has a PCE of 23.4%.
(4)
Several factors, such as high open-circuit voltage (
V
OC
) deficit (
V
OC
-deficit) originating from the altered absorber composition, defects density, cationic disorder, secondary phases, and low carrier lifetime, have been proposed to account for the lower device performance of kesterite.
(5)
The absorber and its grain boundary (GB) interface can also strongly affect kesterite device performance.
(6−8)
In a polycrystalline solar cell, the roles of GB and grain interior (GI) vary by material. In the case of kesterites, a higher surface potential near GBs than in GIs indicates a downward bending of the conduction band from GIs to GBs, which may cause the transport of minority carriers from GIs to GBs upon photoexcitation followed by the collection of an electron by the buffer and window layer.
(9)
GBs are benign for high-performance CIGS devices with different modes of band bending. A similar band-bending phenomenon in kesterite was difficult to correlate.

The variation in a local compositional environment, which significantly affects carrier transport properties, ultimately affects device performance. Therefore, understanding the relationship with device performance is essential and can be studied through nanoscale investigation. Previous reports identified two major factors affecting the band bending and surface potential of the absorber material: (I) defects near the GB and GI interface
(10)
and (II) sulfur (S)/selenium (Se) distribution near the GB and GI interface.
(11)
Li et al.
(10)
studied the atomic and electronic bonding structure with density functional theory in CZTSe and showed that GB defects can be formed in and outside the energy gap of the bulk absorber. Yin et al.
(12)
suggested that undesirable atomic bonding among constituent elements and compositional inhomogeneity amid the films causes the formation of different defect states. Salvador et al.
(11)
showed that although the S/(S+Se) ratio was uneven throughout the films, an increasing S ratio can be correlated with a higher local work function; however, there was no correlation between GBs and GIs. All these inhomogeneities within the films and GB may cause the recombination of photoexcited carriers and reduce device efficiency.

Studies performed in kesterite show that GBs behave oppositely for pure S- and Se-based absorbers, although they exhibit the same composition. Thus, finding an acute solution and the origin of different observed surface potential variations, principally in the mixed kesterite (CZTSSe), remains an area of discussion. Additionally, the role of GBs in the carrier transport of the CZTSSe absorber layer should be elucidated. The positioning of S and Se plays a crucial role in band bending near the GB, leading to higher device performance for mixed CZTSSe. Previous studies address nanoscale measurements, Sn variation, the composition effect, and effects on device performance; however, the relative composition, density of defect clusters, and effect of S distribution on the surface potential have not been extensively highlighted.

The present work aims to understand the compositional dependency of the GB potential and the compositional effect on nanoscale electronic properties; we pointedly modulated the absorber composition by altering the zinc (Zn) to tin (Sn) ratio within the precursor films. The change in the Zn/Sn ratio by Sn amount variation was analyzed by measuring the local electrical properties of the absorber layer and the device at nano- and microscales. Additionally, the effect on compositional inhomogeneity and surface properties were studied by interface imaging and different characterization techniques. We found that the increased Sn content or a reduced Zn/Sn ratio strongly influence S positioning and defect density. Consequently, improved charge carrier separation enhanced device efficiency.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
CZTSSe thin films were prepared by annealing preannealed stacked metallic precursors under a mixed S and Se vapor atmosphere. To fabricate the absorber layer, (1) the stacked metallic precursors with a stacking order of copper (Cu)/Sn/Zn were prepared on a molybdenum (Mo)-coated soda–lime glass by direct current (DC) sputtering. The Sn deposition time varied at 200 s intervals from 1600 to 2200 s, the detailed deposition conditions and sample names of the metallic precursors are listed in
Table S1
. (2) Cu/Sn/Zn/Mo-stacked metallic precursors were annealed at 300 °C for 1 h under an Ar atmosphere to obtain Cu-based alloys with smooth morphologies. (3) Soft-annealed stacked metallic precursors and chalcogen powders were placed in a graphite box in a chamber-type rapid thermal annealing system and the chamber was heated to 520 °C; the temperature was maintained for 7.5 min, and the annealed films were naturally cooled. (4) Solar cell devices were prepared with a multilayered Al/AZO/i-ZnO/CdS/CZTSSe/Mo/glass structure.
(13,14)
Further detailed information regarding the experiments is provided in the
Supporting Information
.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra of the thin films were measured to detect the presence of secondary phases and phase purity in the CZTSSe samples. All of the samples clearly show characteristic kesterite structure peaks (
Figure S1
). A Sn-based secondary phase (Sn(S,Se)
2
with increased Sn concentration) is observed near diffraction angles of 31 and 14° for samples V1 and V2, respectively (
Figure S1
a). The increasing intensity of the Sn(S,Se)
2
peaks validates the abundance of the phase with the increasing Sn content. A small hump near 32° shows the formation of the Mo(S,Se)
2
layer in thin films. The XRD spectra analyzed for the pure kesterite mode at 27.2° shifts to a higher 2θ angle (
Figure S1
b), showing the possibility of accumulation and/or enhanced amounts of S in the absorber surface for Sn-rich samples (V4 < V3 < V2 = V1).
(15)
A decreasing lattice parameter
c
, which specifies the sublattice disorder related to Cu–Zn,
(16−18)
could also shift the (112) peak. The altered composition and elemental abundance within the precursor thin films can strongly affect CZTSSe pathway formation. The Sn-poor samples with rich Cu and Zn compositions may have consumed the formation of secondary phases, such as Sn(S,Se)
2
, during the annealing process by intermediate reactions (
reactions 1
and
2
), which ease the formation of the pure kesterite phase.
(19)
Further, increased amounts of the excess Sn content in the precursor thin films might precipitate as Sn-based secondary phase Sn(S,Se)
2
.
(1)
(2)

Tables S1 and S2
provide the absorber composition measured for the deposited precursor thin films and after the sulfo-selenization process.

Figure
1
shows the surface morphology for samples V1–V4. Larger, compact grains formed as the Sn concentration increased, and the grain sharpness and size increased as the pinhole density decreased. The cross-sectional view acquired for the full device structure (
Figure S2
) also shows the enlarged grain size from V4 to V1. All the samples exhibit a bilayer structure with larger grains at the top and smaller grains at the bottom within a smaller region.

div.p: Figure 1. Field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) images of samples (a) V1, (b) V2, (c) V3, and (d) V4.

div.div:
We performed time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectroscopy (TOF-SIMS) for all samples to better understand the effect of composition on the elemental distribution within the bulk and the interface. The two different representative SIMS profiles of elemental S and alkali sodium (Na) for different Sn contents are considered to determine the distribution effect. Metallic elements show a nearly uniform distribution over the bulk in all samples from V1 to V4 (
Figure S3
). As anticipated, the Sn distribution in samples V1–V4 increased as the Sn content increased. The Sn-rich sample shows a slight profile upshift, whereas the Sn-poor sample shows a slightly lower depth compared to the baseline sample V2. The slight hump at the bottom of sample V1 for Sn and Se shows the probability of the Sn(S,Se)
2
secondary phase near the back interface. Careful observations of all profiles reveal that precursor composition affects the S distribution. All of the samples show a S-rich front surface of the absorber layer with a graded S profile (
Figure
2
a). The S distribution profile, plotted with respect to Sn, shows that sample V4 is Sn-poor; sample V2 has nearly uniform and slightly S-rich profiles in the bulk and at the junction interface, respectively. The exact mechanism underlying the S distribution is not well understood; however, the diffusivity of S during the cooling process, based on the compactness of the absorber layer, may provide this graded profile. Additionally, the distributions of all alkali elements deviate according to the Sn content. Na and potassium (K) follow the same trend and distribution profile (
Figure S4
). All samples show increased Na concentration in the bulk with increased Sn content, except for sample V4, which has extremely low Sn composition (
Figure
2
b). Careful observation revealed that sample V2 has a moderate (compared to those of the other samples) Na concentration in the bulk and increased concentration toward the interface. The Sn-poor samples V3 and V4 have a lower Na accumulation near the interface.

div.p: Figure 2. TOF-SIMS profiles (a) Sn versus S and (b) Sn versus Na for samples V1, V2, V3, and V4.

div.div:
Most of the high-efficiency devices exhibit off-stoichiometric composition (Cu-poor, Zn-rich) conditions, and in these conditions, there is a probability of the occurrence of [Zn
Cu
+ V
Cu
] (A-type) and [2Zn
Cu
+ Zn
Sn
] (B-type) defect clusters. Dimitrievska et al.
(20−22)
showed that the characteristic Raman modes near 170, 196, and 231 cm
–1
can get affected by different defects or cluster concentrations derived from different stoichiometric compositions. Lower frequency modes ranging from 150 to 200 cm
–1
are primarily observed owing to cation vibrations from Cu and Zn atoms; higher frequency modes (200–250 cm
–1
) are caused by Zn and Sn.
(20,23)
Herein, the characteristic Raman modes of CZTSe at 176, 196, and 233 cm
–1
were observed with a small hump at 327 cm
–1
for CZTS (
Figure S5
). The deconvoluted peaks obtained with the Lorentzian fit from 100 to 400 cm
–1
for all spectra show additional peaks for secondary phase ZnSe at 250 cm
–1
(
Figure S6
). Further, all spectra were normalized to the most intense A1 mode of CZTSe at 196 cm
–1
to obtain additional information about the defect densities (
Figure
3
a). The normalized A1 mode of CZTSe reveals a gradual increase and decrease in relative peak intensities at 176, 215, and 233 cm
–1
. The intensities of the A1 mode, which are ascribed to only the Se anion vibration mode and specify the broadening of the peaks due to their structure, do not change.
Figure
3
b shows the evolution of the relative area of the Raman peaks at 176 and 233 cm
–1
as a function of sample composition. The relative area of the peaks was calculated according to a previous report, with which the present experimental observations are consistent.
(20−22)
Following the same tradeline, the relative areas of A-type [Zn
Cu
+ V
Cu
] and B-type [2Zn
Cu
+ Zn
Sn
] defect cluster peaks decreased and increased (but remained constant compared to A) as the Sn concentration increased, respectively. Thus, A-type [Zn
Cu
+ V
Cu
] defects at 176 cm
–1
are much more strongly affected by the increased Sn content than B-type defects at 215 and 233 cm
–1
, owing to low B-type [2Zn
Cu
+ Zn
Sn
] density. The density of B-type [2Zn
Cu
+ Zn
Sn
] defects was probably not influenced by the density of the A-type [Zn
Cu
+ V
Cu
] defect cluster. The reduced area provides information about the increased density of defects, such as V
cu
,
(24)
and indicates that the increased Sn content leads to Cu-poor conditions and promotes the formation of A-type [Zn
Cu
+ V
Cu
] defects validated through the reduced area of 176 modes; this confirms the increase in A-type defect clusters. Among all of the samples, V2 has a slightly high A-type [Zn
Cu
+ V
Cu
] defect cluster area; considering the tendency from samples V4–V1, enhanced Sn increases the defect density, which is consistent with a previous report.
(16)
This increased defect density in sample V1 could have a significant impact on device performance.

div.p:
Figure 3. Raman spectra for samples V1–V4. (a) Normalized Raman spectra at A1 mode for V1–V4 and (b) relative peak areas of A-type [Zn
Cu
+ V
Cu
] (▲) and B-type [2Zn
Cu
+ Zn
Sn
] (■) defects for V1 (black), V2 (red), V3 (blue) and V4 (green) with respect to composition.

div.div:
We performed Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) for CZTSSe thin films to visualize the distribution of the abovementioned defects and compositional variance. The compositional inhomogeneity in kesterite thin films causes potential fluctuations, which can be directly probed using a nanoscale atomic probe force (AFM) tip.
(8,16,25)
Figure
4
a–d shows contact potential difference (CPD) images of samples V1–V4, and
Figure S7
shows the corresponding topography images. Increased Sn concentration in the absorption layer increases the grain size; this agrees with the FE-SEM image results (
Figure
1
). The Sn-rich samples V1 and V2 (
Figure
4
a,b) contain 30–60 nm sized clusters with lower CPD within grains; Raman results indicate that the off-stoichiometric composition that forms A- and B-type defects causes this cluster formation.
(26)
However, decreased Sn concentration in V3 and V4 (
Figure
4
c,d) reduces this number of clusters.
Figure
4
e displays the overall CPD distribution of each sample extracted from the respective CPD maps of the samples. As the Sn concentration increases, a wider CPD distribution (responsible for the clusters) is observed in V1 and V2, whereas V3 and V4 with less Sn exhibit a narrow CPD distribution. Considering the work function of CZTSSe, CPD peaks shift to lower CPD values of −0.11, −0.13, −0.15, and −0.22 V for samples V1–V4, respectively (
Figure
4
e). It indicates that the decreased Sn concentration from V1 to V4 increases the work function of the sample (Φ
sample
= Φ
tip
(5.1 eV) + CPD), owing to excess Cu and reduced Zn, which in turn contributes to shifting the Fermi level into the valence band.
(27,28)
This trend is consistent with the previous literature.
(27)
Figure S8
shows the average CPD at GBs and GIs and the CPD difference between GBs and GIs extracted from CPD spatial maps.
Figure
4
f shows the histogram plots of clusters from each sample. Sample V2 contains the highest number of clusters as the Sn concentration increases. These clusters have relatively higher CPD (40 mV), which could be related to the beneficial secondary phase or A-type defects, resulting in increased drift carriers.
(29,30)

div.p: Figure 4. Contact potential difference (CPD) maps of (a) V1, (b) V2, (c) V3, and (d) V4 in the dark; (e) overall CPD distribution from obtained CPD maps; and (f) histogram of CPD with clusters within grains from CPD maps.

div.div:
Investigating the contentious role of GBs is crucial in solar cells.
(7)
GBs in kesterite solar cells are considered as recombination
(10)
or carrier-collecting
(31)
sites, depending on the composition at the GB.
Figure
5
a,b displays the three-dimensional (3D) topography of V2 and V4.
Figure
5
c,d shows the corresponding CPD images of V2 and V4. All samples showed lower CPD values at GB than at GI in the dark. The lower CPD values at the GB could be responsible for the local negative charge accumulation.
(32,33)
Figure
5
e,f depicts the line profiles of samples V2 and V4 along the red line. The difference between GBs and GIs is ∼30 mV for sample V4 at a low Sn concentration. On the other hand, sample V2 with a high Sn concentration shows the highest difference of ∼60 mV, indicating that strong negative charges exist at the GBs of sample V2. We schematically illustrate the energy band diagram of samples V2 and V4. The negative potential at GBs is associated with upward energy band bending (
Figure
5
g).
(6)
Upward band bending can lead to the repulsion of electrons and attraction holes at the GBs, resulting in higher charge separation. Such upward band bending can also be expected at clusters existing within the grains and could benefit charge separation. Persson et al.
(34)
reported that Cu deficiency near the GB reduces carrier recombination. Accordingly, Raman analysis revealed that the density of the A-type [Zn
Cu
+ V
Cu
] defect cluster and V
cu
increased; these negatively charged defects could benefit this carrier separation process.

div.p: Figure 5. 3D topography of (a) V1 and (b) V2 corresponding to 3D CPD maps of samples (c) V2 and (d) V4; (e, f) red line profile in 3D CPD maps of the samples V2 and V4, respectively. GBs: grain boundaries and GIs: grain interiors; and (g) scheme of the energy band diagram and CPDs surrounding GBs in the dark for samples V2 and V4.

div.div:
Capacitance–voltage (
C
–
V
) and drive-level capacitance profiling (DLCP) measurements were performed to better understand the electrical properties around the heterojunction CZTSSe/CdS interface. Detailed information about the calculation is provided in the
Supporting Information
.
Table S4
shows the
C
–
V
and DLCP measurement results, and
Figure
6
a,b presents the corresponding profiles.
Figure
6
a displays the correlation between the charge carrier densities as a function of the depletion width (
X
d
). The charged carrier concentration extracted from the
C
–
V
measurements at a 0 V bias gives an idea about the responses of free carriers, where
X
d
can be determined from DLCP.
X
d
, one of the key parameters in heterojunction thin-film solar cells, governs two major charge separation and collection processes in the device. The
X
d
of samples V4–V2 increased as the Sn content increased (
Table S4
) and can benefit fast carrier transport across the CZTSSe heterojunction interface. Moreover, the bulk carrier density (
N
DL
) and interface charge carrier density (
N
CV
) determined for samples V4–V2 decreased as the Sn content increased (
Figure
6
b). The observed DLCP carrier density is slightly lower than that of CV, owing to the escaping nature of the charged defects.
(35)
The
N
DL
,
N
CV
, and
X
d
determined for the high-efficiency device were approximately ∼3.6 × 10
16
cm
–3
, ∼4.8 × 10
16
cm
–3
, and ∼50 nm, respectively. The best V2 device shows a relatively wide depletion region compared to sample V4. The difference in carrier concentration is primarily observed because of different Sn contents. The aforementioned results indicate that the charge carrier concentration and
X
d
are very sensitive to relative Sn content and composition.
(36)
The CZTSSe band gap (
E
g
) is sensitive to the precursor composition. Azzouzi et al.
(18)
observed that the
E
g
of the device was altered as the Sn concentration changed and proposed that the
V
OC
of the device is strongly influenced by the density of defects and the interface quality rather than a low nonradiative combination. The steady-state photoluminescence (PL) spectra for samples V2 and V4 were measured in this study. The results show that samples V2 and V4 have
E
g
values of approximately 1.03 and 1.00 eV, respectively (
Figure
6
c). The increased density of the A-type [Zn
Cu
+ V
Cu
] defect cluster and the amount of S near the interface could be responsible for the slight (blue) shift in the
E
g
value and the intensity of the PL peak.
(16)
Moreover, the blue shift can also be observed due to reduced disorder, decreased density of B-type defects [Zn
Cu
+ Cu
Zn
], and/or a relative increase in the density of A-type [V
Cu
+ Zn
Cu
] defects.
(37−39)
These results agree with the Raman analysis. Additionally, carrier lifetime decay (τ) was determined from biexponential fitting;
Table
1
presents the corresponding values. As the Sn atom % in CZTSSe film increased (V4 < V2), the carrier lifetime increases from 0.96 to 1.35 ns (
Figure
6
d), indicating that the lack of Sn in the absorber layer can decrease carrier lifetime. The external quantum efficiency (EQE) measured for sample V2 shows an enhanced optical response in the visible region compared to that for V4 (
Figure S9
). The corresponding
E
g
values determined from EQE measurements are found to be around 1.06 and 1.01 eV for samples V2 and V4, respectively. The improved carrier lifetime and optical response in the visible region for sample V2 reveal the improved bulk quality of the absorber layer.

div.div:
As the composition ratio varies,
V
OC
, fill factor (FF), and PCE get strongly affected. The
V
OC
, FF, and PCE of the devices increased from V4 to V2 and eventually decreased for V1 as the Sn content increased. The
V
OC
of the devices dramatically increased from 418 to 493 mV (15%); FF increased from 53 to 64% (17%), and PCE increased from 6.42 to 11.04% (40%), achieving a maximum efficiency of 11.04% for sample V2. The improved morphology of the absorber and reduced density of pinhole supports enhanced device efficiency and FF. The saturation current density (
J
0
) calculated for all of the samples shows a decreased
J
0
value as the Sn content increases. The liability of
V
OC
and the carrier recombination on
J
0
show that sample V2 has the lowest
J
0
value and high
V
OC
and FF compared to other devices. Reduced
J
0
also validates improved bulk quality and reduced carrier recombination.
(40)
The
E
g
values of samples V2 and V4 were determined from the steady-state PL as well as EQE and
V
OC
-deficit were calculated. Sample V4 has a
V
OC
-deficit of approximately 582 mV, and with an optimal Sn content, a record
V
OC
-deficit of 537 mV was achieved. One of the subcells has a
V
OC
of 497, an efficiency of 10.97% (V2–4,
Table S5
), and a relatively lower
V
OC
-deficit of 533 mV. The
V
OC
-deficit values determined from EQE and
E
g
values are found to be around 567 and 592 mV for samples V2 and V4, respectively. The achieved record
V
OC
-deficit values determined from EQE and RTPL are the best for the CZTSSe based absorber layer. The record
V
OC
-deficit is only compared with CdS as a baseline buffer layer without any postdeposition treatment or doping in the absorber layer.
Table S6
provides a detailed comparison of previously reported
V
OC
-deficit values to those of the present work. Changing absorber composition modifies the reaction pathways, which subsequently affect the formation of secondary phases and different defect clusters. As reported in the previous literature, the nanosupply of the Sn content strongly modulates
V
OC
values.
(18)
Additionally, improved carrier separation and higher minority carrier collection near the GB ease carrier transport properties and enhance the
V
OC
of the device. Widened
X
d
and
E
g
with improved junction quality found in the CV-DLCP analysis support
V
OC
enhancement. The reduced device efficiency for sample V1 can be explained by the following reasons: (i) formation of Sn (S,Se)
2
secondary phases and (ii) enhanced defect cluster density. The formation of high-density A-type defect clusters increases the rate of carrier recombination through the Shockley–Read–Hall mechanism.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Herein, we report the effect of compositional inhomogeneities on absorber morphologies and the corresponding optoelectronic properties of CZTSSe-based thin-film solar cells. As the Sn content increased, the composition ratio of Zn/Sn and Cu/(Zn+Sn) changed significantly. The diverse surface analysis technique proved that absorber morphology improved with the Sn content and the formation of Sn-based secondary phase Sn(S,Se)
2
in Sn-rich samples. The defect density (analyzed through Raman spectroscopy) revealed that the density of the negatively charged A-type [Zn
Cu
+ V
Cu
] defect cluster increased as the Sn content increased. The modulated Sn supply deviates the alkali element distribution and shows a graded S profile with accumulation near the interface region. The synergistic outcome provides a wider depletion region width and improved minority carrier lifetime and carrier separation. We demonstrated that an adequate amount of A-type defect density assists the carrier separation process with a larger CPD value difference among GIs and GBs. However, the enhanced density of defects and secondary phases is detrimental. The device efficiency is enhanced by nearly 40% from 6.42 to 11.04% with optimum elemental composition and device fabrication processes. Additionally,
V
OC
and FF in the V2 device increased from 418 to 494 mV (17%) and from 53 to 64%, respectively, with record
V
OC
-deficit values of 537 and 567 mV determined from PL and EQE, respectively. These findings provide new experimental insights into the microscopic relationships between composition, structure, and electronic properties in kesterite, which may help in improving
V
OC
-deficit characteristics. Nevertheless, further studies are needed to determine the relationship between Sn and S distributions near the interface.

Cu2ZnSnS4 solar cells with over 10% power conversion efficiency enabled by heterojunction heat treatment
Yan, Chang; Huang, Jialiang; Sun, Kaiwen; Johnston, Steve; Zhang, Yuanfang; Sun, Heng; Pu, Aobo; He, Mingrui; Liu, Fangyang; Eder, Katja; Yang, Limei; Cairney, Julie M.; Ekins-Daukes, N. J.; Hameiri, Ziv; Stride, John A.; Chen, Shiyou; Green, Martin A.; Hao, Xiaojing
Nature Energy
(
2018
),
3
(
9
),
764-772
CODEN:
NEANFD
; ISSN:
2058-7546
.
(
Nature Research
)
Sulfide kesterite Cu2ZnSnS4 provides an attractive low-cost, environmentally benign and stable photovoltaic material, yet the record power conversion efficiency for such solar cells has been stagnant at around 9% for years. Severe non-radiative recombination within the heterojunction region is a major cause limiting voltage output and overall performance. Here we report a certified 11% efficiency Cu2ZnSnS4 solar cell with a high 730 mV open-circuit voltage using heat treatment to reduce heterojunction recombination. This heat treatment facilitates elemental inter-diffusion, directly inducing Cd atoms to occupy Zn or Cu lattice sites, and promotes Na accumulation accompanied by local Cu deficiency within the heterojunction region. Consequently, new phases are formed near the hetero-interface and more favorable conduction band alignment is obtained, contributing to reduced non-radiative recombination. Using this approach, we also demonstrate a certified centimetre-scale (1.11 cm2) 10% efficiency Cu2ZnSnS4 photovoltaic device; the first kesterite cell (including selenium-contg.) of std. centimetre-size to exceed 10%.

Effect of solid-H2S gas reactions on CZTSSe thin film growth and photovoltaic properties of a 12.62% efficiency device
Son, Dae-Ho; Kim, Seung-Hyun; Kim, Se-Yun; Kim, Young-Ill; Sim, Jun-Hyung; Park, Si-Nae; Jeon, Dong-Hwan; Hwang, Dae-Kue; Sung, Shi-Joon; Kang, Jin-Kyu; Yang, Kee-Jeong; Kim, Dae-Hwan

We fabricated CZTSSe thin films using optimized SLG-Mo/Zn/Cu/Sn (MZCT) as a stacked structure and described the phenomenon of Zn elemental volatilization using the MZCT stacked structure. We introduced H2S gas to effectively control the S/(S + Se) ratio of the film in the sulfo-selenization process and to suppress Zn volatilization. Unlike during the selenization process, a stable ZnSSe thin film was formed on the precursor surface during the sulfo-selenization process. The formation of the ZnSSe thin film inhibited Zn volatilization, which facilitated control of the thin film stoichiometry and played an important role in crystal growth. In addn., the sulfo-selenization process using H2S forms a grading of the S/(S + Se) ratio in the depth direction in the ZnSSe layer. The ZnSSe layer with this property causes the band gap grading in the CZTSSe absorption layer. Finally, through our optimized annealing process, we realized a world record CZTSSe solar cell with a certified power conversion efficiency of 12.62% and a centimetre-scale (1.1761 cm2) efficiency of 11.28%.

Insights into kesterite's back contact interface: A status review
Karade, Vijay; Lokhande, Abhishek; Babar, Pravin; Gang, Myeng Gil; Suryawanshi, Mahesh; Patil, Pramod; Kim, Jin Hyeok
Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells
(

.
(
Elsevier B.V.
)
Recently, kesterite-based thin film solar cells (TFSCs) gained significant attention in the photovoltaic (PV) sector for their elemental earth abundancy and low toxicity. The emerging kesterite-based Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) TFSCs have gained a steady rise to the record power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 12.6%, which is still significantly lower than its predecessor chalcopyrite Cu(In, Ga)Se2 (CIGS) TFSCs. Relatively the low device efficiency in kesterite-based TFSCs is mainly obsd. due to the instability of back interface during the high temp. thermal annealing (HTTA) process. During the HTTA process the detrimental reactions at Mo/absorber create unsolicited defects like MoS(e)2 layer, secondary phases and voids which consequently reduce the device efficiency. The present review offers some deep insights of the back-contact interface and interface related defects, besides different solns. to overcome these defects in detail. The interfacial-defects like the formation of MoS(e)2 layer, secondary phases and voids at Mo/absorber interface are conversed broadly with their resp. reaction mechanism. Moreover, the plausible band theory of back contact interface in the presence of interfacial MoS(e)2 layer and the criteria for ideal back contact are also addressed. In conclusion, this review envisions the contests and perception for achieving high efficiency in kesterite based TFSCs by signifying an improvement in back interface related defects.

Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) thin-film solar cells have been fabricated by various methods. Sputtering is one of the vacuum processes that can be used for the growth of the precursors. In this study, CZTSSe thin-films that were fabricated using metal-precursors and with a high efficiency of 12.3% were examd. in a comparison with CZTSSe thin-films that were fabricated using compd.-precursors, whose efficiency is 9.1%. Esp., the Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) anal. and local current measurement by conductive at. force microscopy (c-AFM) show that their local elec. properties indicate completely opposite results. The grain boundaries (GBs) has a downward surface potential bending, and this repelled the minority carriers into the intragrains (IGs) in the sample from the metal-precursors. Therefore, we originally verified the differences between the carrier behaviors and the current flows on the surface.

The alterations of carrier separation in kesterite solar cells
Yang, Kee-Jeong; Kim, Sammi; Sim, Jun-Hyoung; Son, Dae-Ho; Kim, Dae-Hwan; Kim, Juran; Jo, William; Yoo, Hyesun; Kim, JunHo; Kang, Jin-Kyu

Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)S4 (CZTSSe) thin films have attracted attention as low-cost absorber materials for solar cells; however, further studies are required to develop flexible solar cells from this material and to achieve a high power conversion efficiency. Toward this objective, this work investigated eight types of precursors applied on flexible Mo foil substrates, some of which also contained a layer of NaF. Secondary phases, defects, and defect clusters were different in the various samples, and the surface elec. characteristics of the CZTSSe absorber layer varied accordingly. In contrast to those in the CIGS-based cells, defects and defect clusters generated in the CZTSSe absorber layer caused an upward band bending-like band structure to form at the grain boundaries (GBs), thereby forming an intra-grain (IG) current path. By improving carrier sepn., a flexible CZTSSe thin-film solar cell was developed on a Mo foil substrate with a power conversion efficiency of 7.04%. Thus, the efficiency of CZTSSe thin-film solar cells could be increased through carrier sepn. measures that enabled the collection of holes toward the GBs and of electrons toward IGs.

Single elementary target-sputtered Cu2ZnSnSe4 thin film solar cells

A simple single elementary target sputtering method is proposed as an alternative to the multi-target sputter approach for prepg. Cu2ZnSnSe4 absorber films. Several single targets utilizing excess Cu and Zn, including Cu2ZnSnSe4, Cu2Zn1.5SnSe4, Cu2.5Zn1.5SnSe4 and Cu3Zn1.5SnSe4, were investigated to det. the absorber film with the most promising structural and photovoltaic performance. A conversion efficiency of ∼4.16% was obtained from the Cu2.5Zn1.5SnSe4 single target, which displayed well-defined grain structures with desirable Zn/Sn and Cu/(Zn+Sn) ratios. Crit. roles of excess Cu and Zn during sputtering are discussed in conjunction with microstructural evolution, elemental distribution, photovoltaic characteristics and grain boundary contributions, which are specified for the sputtering method.

Li, Junwen; Mitzi, David B.; Shenoy, Vivek B.

We have studied the at. and electronic structure of Cu2ZnSnSe4 and CuInSe2 grain boundaries using first-principles calcns. We find that the constituent atoms at the grain boundary in Cu2ZnSnSe4 create localized defect states that promote the recombination of photon-excited electron and hole carriers. In distinct contrast, significantly lower d. of defect states is found at the grain boundaries in CuInSe2, which is consistent with the exptl. observation that CuInSe2 solar cells exhibit high conversion efficiency without the need for deliberate passivation. Our investigations suggest that it is essential to effectively remove these defect states in order to improve the conversion efficiency of solar cells with Cu2ZnSnSe4 as photovoltaic absorber materials.

Thin film solar cells made from Cu, Zn, Sn, and S/Se can be processed from soln. to yield high-performing kesterite (CZTS or CZTSSe) photovoltaics. The authors present a microstructural study of soln.-deposited CZTSSe films prepd. by nanocrystal-based ink approaches using scanning probe microscopy (SPM) and SEM coupled with energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The authors correlate scanning Kelvin probe microscopy (SKPM) maps of local surface potential with SEM/EDS images of the exact same regions of the film, allowing one to relate obsd. variations in surface potential to local variations in stoichiometry. Specifically, a correlation between surface potential and the S/(S + Se) compn. ratio were found. In particular, regions with high S/(S + Se) ratios are often assocd. with regions of more neg. surface potential and thus higher work function. The change in work function is larger than the expected change in the valence band position with these small changes in S, and thus the data suggest an increase in acceptor-like defects with increasing S. These findings provide new exptl. insight into the microscopic relations between compn., structure, and electronic properties in these promising photovoltaic materials.

Through first-principle d. functional theory (DFT) calcns., the at. structure and electronic properties of intrinsic and passivated Σ3 (114) grain boundaries (GBs) in Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) are studied. Intrinsic GBs in CZTSe create localized deep states within the band gap and thus act as Shockley-Read-Hall recombination centers, which are detrimental to cell performance. Defects, such as ZnSn (Zn atoms on Sn sites), Na+i (interstitial Na ions), and OSe (O atoms on Se sites), prefer to segregate into GBs in CZTSe. The segregation of these defects at GBs exhibit two beneficial effects: 1) eliminating the deep gap states via wrong bonds breaking or weakening at GBs, making GBs elec. benign; and 2) creating hole barriers and electron sinkers, promoting effective charge sepn. at GBs. The results suggest a unique chem. approach for engineering GBs in CZTSe to achieve improved cell performance.

In this study, we prepd. three kesterite thin-film solar cells, Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe), Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) and Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS), and based on low-light intensity measurements, examd. the possibility of using kesterite devices for indoor applications. Interestingly, all the prepd. cells exhibited nearly the same device efficiency under std. test conditions of 1 sun, however, under illumination with low-intensity halogen and light-emitting diode lamps (200-400 lx), the power output of CZTSSe was twice that of CZTSe and CZTS. CZTSe (58%) and CZTS (37%) showed relatively larger open-circuit voltage drops than CZTSSe (29%). Suns-Voc measurements revealed that the ideality factor of CZTS and CZTSe increased as the light intensity decreased, which indicates severe recombination caused by deep-level defects at low light intensities. Furthermore, admittance spectroscopy measurements revealed that CZTSe and CZTS have deep trap energy levels, whereas CZTSSe has comparatively shallower trap energy levels, this validates the rapid open-circuit voltage drop under low-light intensity conditions. Kelvin probe force microscopy measurements showed that CZTSSe exhibited a higher photovoltage (86 mV) under illumination at 400 lx compared with that under dark conditions. In addn., our results indicated that the CZTSSe sample showed relatively much higher charge sepn. at GBs (grain boundaries) owing to the downward band bending at the GBs. The findings revealed that for deeper energy levels, the open-circuit voltage redn. was faster, in addn., an absorber layer with shallower defects and efficient charge sepn. at the GBs can induce high-power conversion efficiency under low-light conditions.

Photodetectors have large applications in the current ongoing pandemic. These can be used to study the growth of viruses where depending upon the concn. the light intensity will be reduced. Since the viruses grow very fast therefore a device with very low response time as well as quick recovery will be useful for this study. If the device can be made from the non-toxic materials and sizes are quite small, they can be used for in vitro studies as well. Kesterite Cu2ZnSn(S, Se)4 (CZTSSe) thin film can be deposited over flexible substrates. The detectivity of even very small area device is very high with ultra-small response and recovery time. The CZTSSe PD exhibited excellent broadband (Vis-NIR) photoresponse, high responsivity of 18.0 mA. W-1, a fast rise time of 82 ms, and a decay time of 97 ms, as well as high detectivity (∼109 Jones) with favorable self-powered characteristics. This work suggests significant scientific insights for photocond. properties of emerging kesterite CZTSSe thin-film materials for broadband, low-cost, high-efficiency next-generation thin-film photodetectors for various optoelectronic applications including diagnostic.

In this study, we investigate the elec., structural, and optical properties of band gap front-graded Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) thin films grown by a modified single-step sulfo-selenization process from copper-poor and zinc-rich precursor metallic stacks prepd. by co-evapn. To investigate how the bandgap was graded in connection with the compositional distribution, we calcd. the bandgap energy distribution along the film thickness, based on the transmission electron microscopy and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy compn. profile. The band gap of the CZTSSe phase with high S content near the surface layer is detd. to be 1.161 eV. From the surface to the bottom, there is a decrease in the S content of the CZTSSe phase, and the band gap subsequently decreases to, 1.029 eV, close to the value of CZTSe. From the results of dimpling-Raman and scanning transmission electron microscopy line scanning, we confirm that the S content drastically increases from the bottom to the top surface of the CZTSSe thin film. The CZTSSe thin-film solar cell exhibits a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 10.33%, with an open-circuit voltage (Voc) of 0.505 V, short-circuit c.d. (Jsc) of 31.61 mA/cm2, fill factor (FF) of 64.6%, and Voc deficit of 525 mV. Compared with the performance of the CZTSe solar cell, which had PCE of 7.23%, Voc of 0.424 V, Jsc of 32.83 mA cm-2, FF of 51.9%, and Voc deficit of 576 mV, the Voc and Voc deficit of the CZTSSe cell improved considerably. The high Voc, low Voc deficit, and less loss of Jsc are attributed to the effect of band gap front-grading induced by S grading into the CZTSSe thin film.

Kesterite thin films solar cells have been studied in recent years as a potential earth abundant alternative to other thin film technologies such as the ones based on the chalcopyrite Cu(In,Ga)Se2 (CIGS). However, the efficiency of the kesterite devices is still low and needs further development. In order to increase the performance of the kesterite solar cells, a better understanding of the influence of variations of compns. on the crystal lattice of the absorber layer is needed. This paper presents a study of how variations in the Cu content in the Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) absorber layer affects the crystal structure and therefore changes the optoelectronic properties of the solar cell. Three sets of CZTSe absorbers with different Cu content were synthesized by sputtering of metallic targets followed by a rapid thermal selenisation process. An accurate characterization of the lattice parameters of the unit cell is presented, showing that a decrease of the Cu content in the CZTSe absorber layer diminishes the unit cell vol. This decrease in vol. is related to an increase in the concn. of [VCu+ZnCu] and the ordering of the Cu/Zn atoms in the (001) plane. The variations in the lattice of CZTSe induced by decreasing the Cu content cause an increase of the bandgap of absorber layer, which leads to an increase of the open circuit voltage (VOC) in the devices. The best solar cell was based on the absorber layer with the lowest Cu content and yielded an efficiency of 8.1% with a fill factor of 59.8%, Jsc=31.1 mA/cm2 and Voc=434 mV.

The performance of kesterite (Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4, CZTSSe) solar cells is hindered by low open circuit voltage (Voc). The commonly used metric for Voc-deficit, namely, the difference between the absorber band gap and qVoc, is not well-defined for compositionally complex absorbers like kesterite where the bandgap is hard to det. Here, nonradiative voltage losses are analyzed by measuring the radiative limit of Voc, using external quantum efficiency (EQE) and electroluminescence (EL) spectra, without relying on precise knowledge of the bandgap. The method is applied to a series of Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 devices with Sn content variation from 27.6-32.9 at. % and a corresponding Voc range from 423-465 mV. Surprisingly, the lowest nonradiative loss, and hence the highest external luminescence efficiency (QELED), were obtained for the device with the lowest Voc. The trend is assigned to better interface quality between absorber and CdS buffer layer at lower Sn content.

Dimitrievska, Mirjana; Oliva, Florian; Guc, Maxim; Giraldo, Sergio; Saucedo, Edgardo; Perez-Rodriguez, Alejandro; Izquierdo-Roca, Victor

Polycryst. kesterite Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) semiconductors have drawn attention as promising absorber candidates for the next generation of thin film photovoltaics. However, the narrow tolerance to stoichiometry variations, which favors the formation of secondary phases and cluster defects, is a challenging drawback that restrains the device performance. In this context Raman spectroscopy has been demonstrated to be a powerful tool for the characterization of CZTSe, allowing the assessment of relevant parameters such as structure, crystal quality and secondary phases. In this work, multiwavelength Raman scattering measurements using nine excitation wavelengths (from 325 to 1064 nm) were performed on CZTSe polycryst. thin films in order to give a detailed identification of all the active Raman modes expected in this cryst. structure. The exptl. results compare well with the vibrational properties that have been computed by first-principles calcns. based on d. functional theory. Calcns. of the phonon d. of states (PDOS), as well as the simulation of the Raman spectra, have allowed a better understanding of the exptl. obsd. vibrational modes. A "non-band gap resonant" Raman effect was obsd. under 325 nm excitation conditions, making ultra-violet (UV) Raman spectroscopy a very promising characterization technique due to its high sensitivity to the surface region which provides information on the buffer/absorber interface. Strong intensity enhancement of spectral regions around 176 cm-1 and 250 cm-1 is obsd. Calcd. PDOS and combinatorial expts. on more than 200 samples with stoichiometries close to the high efficiency device compns. lead to the correlation of these intensities with the concn. of VCu and ZnSn point defects, resp. Correlation with the optoelectronic properties of the devices allowed identification of the optimal concn. of VCu and ZnSn point defects for the highest performance devices. The application of the presented methodol. has been confirmed by performing the same Raman anal. on the CZTSe absorber with 11% device efficiency. This work demonstrates that defect engineering in CZTSe is of the foremost importance for the improvement of solar cell performance, and that UV-based Raman spectroscopy is an effective technique for the non-destructive assessment of defects in kesterite materials.

Dimitrievska, Mirjana; Fairbrother, Andrew; Saucedo, Edgardo; Perez-Rodriguez, Alejandro; Izquierdo-Roca, Victor

Low open circuit voltage (VOC) has been recognized as one of the principle limitations in the current generation of kesterite based solar cells. In order to investigate the origin and possible soln. for this problem, the influence of point defects and secondary phases on the performance of Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) devices is explored. Compositionally graded CZTSe films have been prepd. with nearly 200 solar cells, each with minute changes in cation compn. Systematic structural characterization of these absorbers with Raman spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction is used to detect secondary phases and defect clusters, and their relative concn. is correlated to device properties. The presented results show the exptl. evidence of the effect of the Cu-substitutional defects, in particular [VCu+ZnCu], on the optoelectronic properties, esp. VOC. It is shown that VOC can be tuned by adjusting compn., and consequently the amt. of the [VCu+ZnCu] defect clusters. Furthermore, it is proven that this is intrinsic property of the CZTSe material, independent of the synthesis and post-deposition processes used for the prepn. of samples. Secondary phases are also found to influence device properties, and their effects are dependent on whether they are present in the bulk or surface of the absorber.

Lin, Yi-Cheng; Wang, Li-Ching; Liu, Kuan-Ting; Syu, Ya-Ru; Hsu, Hung-Ru

Our objective in this study was to elucidate the influence of the Zn/Sn ratio (ZTR) in the absorber layer on the formation of secondary phases, leakage current pathways, and the thickness of the MoSe2 layer in Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) solar cells. Expt. results revealed that under Zn-rich conditions (ZTR ≥1.11), the bottom of the absorber layer contains small quantities of Cu2-XSe and SnSe2 secondary phases. Under Sn-rich conditions (ZTR ≤0.75), large quantities of SnSe, SnSe2, and Cu2SnSe3 secondary phases appeared on the surface of the absorber layer. Conductive at. force microscopy (C-AFM) revealed that the presence of secondary phases caused leakage current over large areas at the surface of the absorber layer. We detd. that Cu2-XSe is involved in leakage current at CZTSe grain boundaries, whereas SnSe2 or Cu2SnSe3 tend to promote leakage current in the grains (or near grain boundaries). A higher ZTR resulted in a thinner MoSe2 layer due to large quantities of Cu and Na at the bottom of Zn-rich ZTR specimens, which promoted the formation of Cu2-xSe and Na2Se phases. These phases competed with the Mo to react with the Se, which decreased the amt. of the MoSe2 formed from Se and Mo, resulting in a thinner MoSe2 layer. The highest conversion efficiency (5.2%) was obtained from a Zn-rich specimen (ZTR1.43). In contrast, the Sn-rich specimens (ZTR0.75 and ZTR0.63) presented conversion efficiency of 0%. The influence of ZTR on device performance can be attributed to widespread leakage current due to excessive quantities of SnSe2 and Cu2SnSe3 secondary phases on the surface of the absorber layer. An overly thick MoSe2 layer was also shown to result in excessive series resistance.

A direct mapping of photovoltage in a complete Mo/CZTSSe/CdS/ZnO/Al:ZnO solar cell device is carried out using Kelvin probe force microscopic (KPFM) measurements in surface and junction modes. Four cells having different values of open circuit voltage (VOC) have been studied, and nanoscale variation of photovoltage have been obtained from the difference of surface potential (SP) images in the two modes. The maps exhibit a higher photovoltage at grain boundaries in general. Obsd. SP image of pristine CZTSe layer reveals downward band bending resulting in redn. of carrier recombination, and thus, lower Jdark at grain boundaries (GB). The obsd. downward band bending resulting in low Jdark at GB in CZTSe layer is used to explain the increase in photovoltage (VOC) at the GB. KPFM measurements of CZTSe and CZTSe/CdS layers show that the surface potential of CZTSe layer and its variation can be affected by CdS deposition and further device processing, in addn. to surface adsorption and contamination effects. The photovoltage mapping obtained from Kelvin probe force microscopic measurements on the final device without any interfering effects, is an important advantage of the present method.

Thin films of Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) were synthesized via a low cost, wet chem. technique of chem. bath deposition (CBD). In the first part of this study, the chem. compn. ratio S/(Cu+Zn+Sn) was varied keeping Cu/(Zn + Sn) and Zn/Sn ratios const. to study the effect of sulfur variation. Detailed elec. and optical characterization has been carried out using UV-visible spectroscopy, x-ray diffraction, XPS, Raman spectroscopy and Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) techniques. The results of the present study confirm that near ideal stoichiometry could be achieved in CZTS by adding excess thiourea in a controlled manner which eliminated the need for an addnl. step of sulfurization. Using the stoichiometric sample as the basis, in the second part of the study Cu/(Zn+Sn) and Zn/Sn was varied and it was found that the electronic properties of CZTS in terms of band gap, work function and valence band edge position could be controlled by precursor variation. KPFM was used to qual. evaluate the photoresponse of the films and the Cu-poor, Zn-rich samples showed the best photoresponse out of all the samples which has been attributed to a decrease in the CuZn type defects. The study thus demonstrates a scalable and low-cost technique to grow CZTS absorber layers for solar cells with control over its electronic properties which is important for effective device operation.

We investigated limitation factors of high efficiency Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) solar cells, where the CZTSSe absorbers were made by using sulfo-selenization process. CZTSSe absorbers with two S/(S+Se) ratios, ∼ 0.12 (Se-rich) and ∼ 0.22 (S-increased), were prepd. by varying the sulfo-selenization temp. The Se-rich CZTSSe solar cells were found to have larger conduction band offset (CBO) between the absorber and the buffer, which was reflected in the kinked J-V curves at low temps. Considering that the larger CBO prevents electron transport from absorber to buffer and resultantly reduces short circuit current and fill factor, it could be possible limitation factor of the high efficiency solar cell. Contrary to Se-rich solar cells, S-increased solar cells showed reduced CBO and no kinked J-V curve. However, deep defects were found to be generated, which induced defect centers of charge recombination both at interface and in bulk of the absorber. The larger CBO in Se-rich CZTSSe solar cell and deep defects in S-increased CZTSSe solar cell are obsd. even in ∼ 12% efficiency solar cells. Thus, we believe that these possible limitation factors should be resolved to achieve high efficiency kesterite CZTSSe solar cell above 12%.

A review. A recent meeting of experts in kesterite, chalcopyrite, and related thin-film solar cell devices; characterization; and modeling from industry, academia, and national labs identified high-impact pathways forward in kesterite photovoltaics research, towards the end-goal of achieving high-efficiency (>18%) devices in an accelerated time frame. This paper summarizes the conclusions of this meeting while providing background on key areas of kesterite research. This paper does not aim to provide a comprehensive status-of-the-field review but rather to suggest specific and targeted areas where addnl. focus might yield the highest-impact results.

Solution processing of earth-abundant Cu2ZnSn(S1-x,Sex)4 (CZTSSe) absorber materials is an attractive research area in the economical and large-scale deployment of photovoltaics. Here, a band-gap-graded CZTSSe thin-film solar cell with 7.1% efficiency was developed using non-toxic solvent-based ink without the involvement of complex particle synthesis, highly toxic solvents, or organic additives. Despite the high series resistance due to the presence of a thick Mo(S,Se)x layer and Zn(S,Se) aggregates, a high short-circuit current density (JSC) was generated. In addition, there was no significant difference in open circuit voltages (VOC) between CZTS (0.517 V) and CZTSSe (0.505-0.479 V) cells, despite a significant band gap change from 1.51 eV to 1.24 eV. The high JSC and less loss of VOC are attributed to the effect of band gap grading induced by Se grading in the CZTSSe absorber layer. Our environmentally benign ink approach will enable the realization of low-cost, large-area, high-efficiency thin-film solar cells.

Scanning Kelvin probe microscopy measurements carried out reveal a higher pos. surface potential at the grain boundaries as compared to the grain while conductive at. force microscopy measurements show higher current flow in the vicinity of the grain boundaries. These two measurement results are similar to those obtained for Cu(In,Ga)Se2 and CdTe and together they demonstrate the enhanced minority carrier collection taking place at the grain boundaries of copper zinc tin sulfide (CZTS) and copper zinc tin sulfide selenide (CZTSSe). Since grain boundaries are the key to achieving high efficiencies in polycryst. solar cells and CZTS and CZTSSe solar cells have the same beneficial grain boundary electronic properties as Cu(In,Ga)Se2 and CdTe, we theorize that CZTS and CZTSSe solar cells have the potential to achieve the high efficiencies that Cu(In,Ga)Se2 and CdTe solar cells enjoy. This work has shown that the goal of achieving a low-cost, high efficiency solar cell composed of earth-abundant, non-toxic elements could be made possible through CZTS and CZTSSe thin-film solar cells.

Passive grain boundaries (GBs) are essential for polycryst. solar cells to reach high efficiency. However, the GBs in Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 have less favorable defect chem. compared to CuInGaSe2. Here, using scanning probe microscopy we show that lithium doping of Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 changes the polarity of the elec. field at the GB such that minority carrier electrons are repelled from the GB. Solar cells with lithium-doping show improved performance and yield a new efficiency record of 11.8% for hydrazine-free soln.-processed Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4. We propose that lithium competes for copper vacancies (forming benign isoelectronic LiCu defects) decreasing the concn. of ZnCu donors and competes for zinc vacancies (forming a LiZn acceptor that is likely shallower than CuZn). Both phenomena may explain the order of magnitude increase in cond. Further, the effects of lithium doping reported here establish that extrinsic species are able to alter the nanoscale elec. fields near the GBs in Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4. This will be essential for this low-cost Earth abundant element semiconductor to achieve efficiencies that compete with CuInGaSe2 and CdTe.

Environmentally friendly earth-abundant Cd-free Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) solar cells have recently achieved increasing power conversion efficiency by using ZnSnO as the buffer layer. However, the large open circuit voltage (Voc) deficit remains the key concern. Here, we report a Cd-free CZTS solar cell that exhibits an energy conversion efficiency of 10.2% resulting from the application of an aluminum oxide (Al2O3) passivation layer prepd. by at. layer deposition (ALD). We found that the application of full ALD cycles as well as trimethylaluminum (TMA) exposures resulted in a significant increase in Voc and relate this to the properties of the CZTS interface. Both processes facilitate the formation of a thicker Cu-deficient nanolayer with a higher concn. of Na and O, forming a homogeneous passivation layer across the CZTS surface. This nanolayer reduces the local potential fluctuation of band edges and leads to the widened elec. band gap and suppressed defects recombination at the heterojunction interface, thus improvement in Voc and device performance. The ability of nanolayers to alter the at. compn. in the near surface region of compd. semiconductors might be beneficial for a wider range of semiconductor devices.

First-principles modeling of grain boundaries (GB) in CuInSe2 semiconductors reveals that an energetic barrier exists for holes arriving from the grain interior (GI) to the GB. Consequently, the absence of holes inside the GB prevents GB electrons from recombining. At the same time, the GI is purer in polymaterials than in single crystals, since impurities segregated to the GBs. This explains the puzzle of the superiority of polycryst. CuInSe2 solar cells over their cryst. counterpart. The authors identify a simple and universal mechanism for the barrier, arising from reduced p-d repulsion due to Cu-vacancy surface reconstruction. This discovery opens up possibilities for the future design of superior polycryst. devices.

High performance Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) solar cells are fabricated by selenization of the precursor films of Mo/Sn/Cu/ZnS/Sn/ZnS/Cu deposited by magnetron sputtering. The investigation of the solar cells with different Zn/Sn ratio in CZTSSe film discloses that the charge carrier concn. and depletion region width of the device is very sensitive to Zn/Sn ratio of CZTSSe layer. The CZTSSe film with Zn/Sn=1.05 has lower carrier d. (5.0×1015 cm-3), which is half of the cell with Zn/Sn=1.12, whereas the depletion region at the CdS/CZTSSe hetero-junction interface of the former (200-250 nm) is 100 nm longer than the latter. As a result, better collection of photo-generated charge carrier is found with the cell with longer Wd in the longer wavelength region above 800 nm. Therefore, the av. power conversion efficiency is increased from 6.53% to 9.16% with enlarged depletion region width, and the best performance with 10.2% efficiency is achieved.

Band gap change induced by defect complexes in Cu2ZnSnS4
Huang, Dan; Persson, Clas
Thin Solid Films
(
2013
),
535
(
),
265-269
CODEN:
THSFAP
; ISSN:
0040-6090
.
(
Elsevier B.V.
)
Understanding the impact on the electronic and optical properties of kesterite Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 due to the presence of native defects is crucial for designing and manufg. efficient solar cells. In this work, we complement earlier published theor. studies by investigating the change in the Cu2ZnSnS4 band gap energy induced by the dominating isovalent (ZnCu + CuZn) and (ZnCu + VCu) defect complexes and the corresponding larger [(ZnCu + CuZn) + (ZnCu + VCu)] complex. The study is based on the generalized gradient approxn. with corrections for on-site Coulomb interactions (GGA + U) and the Heyd-Scuseria-Ernzerh hybrid functional method (HSE06) within the first-principles d. functional theory. We find that (ZnCu + CuZn) and (ZnCu + VCu) affect the band gap energies in an opposite way: (ZnCu + CuZn) decreases the gap whereas (ZnCu + VCu) increases the gap. However, there is a strong correlation between these two defect complexes. The presence of the Cu-poor (ZnCu + VCu) defect complex lowers the formation energy of the antisite (ZnCu + CuZn) defect complex in close configuration, and vice versa. Thereby, and considering the opposite effect on the band gap for (ZnCu + CuZn) and (ZnCu + VCu), our results indicate that the band gap energy will be compensated and stabilized in Cu-poor Cu2ZnSnS4. We discuss the underlying mechanisms behind the band gap physics of the considered isovalent defect complexes.

Influence of the copper content on the optical properties of CZTSe thin films
Yakushev, M. V.; Sulimov, M. A.; Marquez-Prieto, J.; Forbes, I.; Krustok, J.; Edwards, P. R.; Zhivulko, V. D.; Borodavchenko, O. M.; Mudryi, A. V.; Martin, R. W.

We present an optical spectroscopy study of Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) thin films deposited on Mo/glass substrates. The [Cu]/[Zn+Sn] ratio in these films varies from nearly stoichiometric to strongly Cu deficient and Zn rich. Increasing Cu deficiency and Zn excess widens the bandgap Eg, detd. using photoluminescence excitation (PLE) at 4.2 K, from 0.99 eV to 1.03 eV and blue shifts the dominant band in the photoluminescence (PL) spectra from 0.83 eV to 0.95 eV. The PL spectra of the near stoichiometric film reveal two bands: a dominant band centered at 0.83 eV and a lower intensity one at 0.93 eV. The temp. and excitation intensity dependence of the PL spectra help to identify the recombination mechanisms of the obsd. emission bands as free-to-bound: recombination of free electrons with holes localised at acceptors affected by randomly distributed potential fluctuations. Both the mean depth of such fluctuations, detd. by analyzing the shape of the dominant bands, and the broadening energy, estd. from the PLE spectra, become smaller with increasing Cu deficiency and Zn excess which also widens Eg due to an improved ordering of the Cu/Zn atoms. These changes in the elemental compn. induce a significant blue shift of the PL bands exceeding the Eg widening. This is attributed to a change of the dominant acceptor for a shallow one, and is beneficial for the solar cell performance. Film regions with a higher degree of Cu/Zn ordering are present in the near stoichiometric film generating the second PL band at 0.93 eV.

Reducing the interfacial defect density of CZTSSe solar cells by Mn substitution
Lie, Stener; Rui Tan, Joel Ming; Li, Wenjie; Leow, Shin Woei; Tay, Ying Fan; Bishop, Douglas M.; Gunawan, Oki; Wong, Lydia Helena
Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability
(
2018
),
6
(
4
),
1540-1550

JMCAET
; ISSN:
2050-7496
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
Cation disorder which arises from the size and chem. environment similarity of Cu and Zn is the limiting factor in Cu2ZnSnSxSe4-x (CZTSSe) performance. Cation substitution is one effective way to solve this issue, however, the most commonly reported substitutes, Ag and Cd, are not ideal as they detract from the earth-abundant and non-toxic motivation of CZTSSe. Mn is a promising candidate in comparison with other candidates (e.g. Fe, Ni or Co), because of its oxidn. state stability and larger ionic size mismatch with Cu. In this study, Cu2MnxZn1-xSn(S,Se)4 (CMZTSSe) thin film solar cells were prepd. by chem. spray pyrolysis and a subsequent selenization process. We study the influence of Mn substitution on the morphol., structural, optical, elec. and device properties. A distinct phase transformation from CZTSSe kesterite to C(M,Z)TSSe stannite is obsd. at 20% Mn substitution. A high amt. of Mn substitution (x ≥ 0.6) is shown to increase the carrier d. significantly which introduces more defects and non-radiative carrier recombination as shown by quenched photoluminescence intensity. Consequently, redn. in device performance is obsd. for these samples. The highest power conversion efficiency is achieved at x ≈ 0.05 with η = 7.59%, Voc = 0.43 V, Jsc = 28.9 mA cm-2 and FF = 61.03%. The improved open circuit voltage (Voc) and fill factor (FF) are attributed to the improved shunt resistance and carrier transport due to low defect d. esp. at the CdS/CMZTSSe interface. Finally, based on our elec. characterization, a few suggestions to improve the efficiency are proposed.

Cu2ZnSnS4 solar cells with over 10% power conversion efficiency enabled by heterojunction heat treatment
Yan, Chang; Huang, Jialiang; Sun, Kaiwen; Johnston, Steve; Zhang, Yuanfang; Sun, Heng; Pu, Aobo; He, Mingrui; Liu, Fangyang; Eder, Katja; Yang, Limei; Cairney, Julie M.; Ekins-Daukes, N. J.; Hameiri, Ziv; Stride, John A.; Chen, Shiyou; Green, Martin A.; Hao, Xiaojing
Nature Energy
(
2018
),
3
(
9
),
764-772
CODEN:
NEANFD
; ISSN:
2058-7546
.
(
Nature Research
)
Sulfide kesterite Cu2ZnSnS4 provides an attractive low-cost, environmentally benign and stable photovoltaic material, yet the record power conversion efficiency for such solar cells has been stagnant at around 9% for years. Severe non-radiative recombination within the heterojunction region is a major cause limiting voltage output and overall performance. Here we report a certified 11% efficiency Cu2ZnSnS4 solar cell with a high 730 mV open-circuit voltage using heat treatment to reduce heterojunction recombination. This heat treatment facilitates elemental inter-diffusion, directly inducing Cd atoms to occupy Zn or Cu lattice sites, and promotes Na accumulation accompanied by local Cu deficiency within the heterojunction region. Consequently, new phases are formed near the hetero-interface and more favorable conduction band alignment is obtained, contributing to reduced non-radiative recombination. Using this approach, we also demonstrate a certified centimetre-scale (1.11 cm2) 10% efficiency Cu2ZnSnS4 photovoltaic device; the first kesterite cell (including selenium-contg.) of std. centimetre-size to exceed 10%.

Son, Dae-Ho; Kim, Seung-Hyun; Kim, Se-Yun; Kim, Young-Ill; Sim, Jun-Hyung; Park, Si-Nae; Jeon, Dong-Hwan; Hwang, Dae-Kue; Sung, Shi-Joon; Kang, Jin-Kyu; Yang, Kee-Jeong; Kim, Dae-Hwan

We fabricated CZTSSe thin films using optimized SLG-Mo/Zn/Cu/Sn (MZCT) as a stacked structure and described the phenomenon of Zn elemental volatilization using the MZCT stacked structure. We introduced H2S gas to effectively control the S/(S + Se) ratio of the film in the sulfo-selenization process and to suppress Zn volatilization. Unlike during the selenization process, a stable ZnSSe thin film was formed on the precursor surface during the sulfo-selenization process. The formation of the ZnSSe thin film inhibited Zn volatilization, which facilitated control of the thin film stoichiometry and played an important role in crystal growth. In addn., the sulfo-selenization process using H2S forms a grading of the S/(S + Se) ratio in the depth direction in the ZnSSe layer. The ZnSSe layer with this property causes the band gap grading in the CZTSSe absorption layer. Finally, through our optimized annealing process, we realized a world record CZTSSe solar cell with a certified power conversion efficiency of 12.62% and a centimetre-scale (1.1761 cm2) efficiency of 11.28%.

Insights into kesterite's back contact interface: A status review
Karade, Vijay; Lokhande, Abhishek; Babar, Pravin; Gang, Myeng Gil; Suryawanshi, Mahesh; Patil, Pramod; Kim, Jin Hyeok
Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells
(
2019
),

(
),
109911
CODEN:
SEMCEQ
; ISSN:
0927-0248
.
(
Elsevier B.V.
)
Recently, kesterite-based thin film solar cells (TFSCs) gained significant attention in the photovoltaic (PV) sector for their elemental earth abundancy and low toxicity. The emerging kesterite-based Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) TFSCs have gained a steady rise to the record power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 12.6%, which is still significantly lower than its predecessor chalcopyrite Cu(In, Ga)Se2 (CIGS) TFSCs. Relatively the low device efficiency in kesterite-based TFSCs is mainly obsd. due to the instability of back interface during the high temp. thermal annealing (HTTA) process. During the HTTA process the detrimental reactions at Mo/absorber create unsolicited defects like MoS(e)2 layer, secondary phases and voids which consequently reduce the device efficiency. The present review offers some deep insights of the back-contact interface and interface related defects, besides different solns. to overcome these defects in detail. The interfacial-defects like the formation of MoS(e)2 layer, secondary phases and voids at Mo/absorber interface are conversed broadly with their resp. reaction mechanism. Moreover, the plausible band theory of back contact interface in the presence of interfacial MoS(e)2 layer and the criteria for ideal back contact are also addressed. In conclusion, this review envisions the contests and perception for achieving high efficiency in kesterite based TFSCs by signifying an improvement in back interface related defects.

Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) thin-film solar cells have been fabricated by various methods. Sputtering is one of the vacuum processes that can be used for the growth of the precursors. In this study, CZTSSe thin-films that were fabricated using metal-precursors and with a high efficiency of 12.3% were examd. in a comparison with CZTSSe thin-films that were fabricated using compd.-precursors, whose efficiency is 9.1%. Esp., the Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) anal. and local current measurement by conductive at. force microscopy (c-AFM) show that their local elec. properties indicate completely opposite results. The grain boundaries (GBs) has a downward surface potential bending, and this repelled the minority carriers into the intragrains (IGs) in the sample from the metal-precursors. Therefore, we originally verified the differences between the carrier behaviors and the current flows on the surface.

Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)S4 (CZTSSe) thin films have attracted attention as low-cost absorber materials for solar cells; however, further studies are required to develop flexible solar cells from this material and to achieve a high power conversion efficiency. Toward this objective, this work investigated eight types of precursors applied on flexible Mo foil substrates, some of which also contained a layer of NaF. Secondary phases, defects, and defect clusters were different in the various samples, and the surface elec. characteristics of the CZTSSe absorber layer varied accordingly. In contrast to those in the CIGS-based cells, defects and defect clusters generated in the CZTSSe absorber layer caused an upward band bending-like band structure to form at the grain boundaries (GBs), thereby forming an intra-grain (IG) current path. By improving carrier sepn., a flexible CZTSSe thin-film solar cell was developed on a Mo foil substrate with a power conversion efficiency of 7.04%. Thus, the efficiency of CZTSSe thin-film solar cells could be increased through carrier sepn. measures that enabled the collection of holes toward the GBs and of electrons toward IGs.

A simple single elementary target sputtering method is proposed as an alternative to the multi-target sputter approach for prepg. Cu2ZnSnSe4 absorber films. Several single targets utilizing excess Cu and Zn, including Cu2ZnSnSe4, Cu2Zn1.5SnSe4, Cu2.5Zn1.5SnSe4 and Cu3Zn1.5SnSe4, were investigated to det. the absorber film with the most promising structural and photovoltaic performance. A conversion efficiency of ∼4.16% was obtained from the Cu2.5Zn1.5SnSe4 single target, which displayed well-defined grain structures with desirable Zn/Sn and Cu/(Zn+Sn) ratios. Crit. roles of excess Cu and Zn during sputtering are discussed in conjunction with microstructural evolution, elemental distribution, photovoltaic characteristics and grain boundary contributions, which are specified for the sputtering method.

We have studied the at. and electronic structure of Cu2ZnSnSe4 and CuInSe2 grain boundaries using first-principles calcns. We find that the constituent atoms at the grain boundary in Cu2ZnSnSe4 create localized defect states that promote the recombination of photon-excited electron and hole carriers. In distinct contrast, significantly lower d. of defect states is found at the grain boundaries in CuInSe2, which is consistent with the exptl. observation that CuInSe2 solar cells exhibit high conversion efficiency without the need for deliberate passivation. Our investigations suggest that it is essential to effectively remove these defect states in order to improve the conversion efficiency of solar cells with Cu2ZnSnSe4 as photovoltaic absorber materials.

Thin film solar cells made from Cu, Zn, Sn, and S/Se can be processed from soln. to yield high-performing kesterite (CZTS or CZTSSe) photovoltaics. The authors present a microstructural study of soln.-deposited CZTSSe films prepd. by nanocrystal-based ink approaches using scanning probe microscopy (SPM) and SEM coupled with energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The authors correlate scanning Kelvin probe microscopy (SKPM) maps of local surface potential with SEM/EDS images of the exact same regions of the film, allowing one to relate obsd. variations in surface potential to local variations in stoichiometry. Specifically, a correlation between surface potential and the S/(S + Se) compn. ratio were found. In particular, regions with high S/(S + Se) ratios are often assocd. with regions of more neg. surface potential and thus higher work function. The change in work function is larger than the expected change in the valence band position with these small changes in S, and thus the data suggest an increase in acceptor-like defects with increasing S. These findings provide new exptl. insight into the microscopic relations between compn., structure, and electronic properties in these promising photovoltaic materials.

Through first-principle d. functional theory (DFT) calcns., the at. structure and electronic properties of intrinsic and passivated Σ3 (114) grain boundaries (GBs) in Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) are studied. Intrinsic GBs in CZTSe create localized deep states within the band gap and thus act as Shockley-Read-Hall recombination centers, which are detrimental to cell performance. Defects, such as ZnSn (Zn atoms on Sn sites), Na+i (interstitial Na ions), and OSe (O atoms on Se sites), prefer to segregate into GBs in CZTSe. The segregation of these defects at GBs exhibit two beneficial effects: 1) eliminating the deep gap states via wrong bonds breaking or weakening at GBs, making GBs elec. benign; and 2) creating hole barriers and electron sinkers, promoting effective charge sepn. at GBs. The results suggest a unique chem. approach for engineering GBs in CZTSe to achieve improved cell performance.
